natural problem: Find all solutions to the equation $\displaystyle\sqrt[3]{3 - x} = -\frac{3}{2}$.
natural solution: We get rid of the cube root sign by cubing both sides. This gives us $3-x = -\frac{27}{8}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "root 3 (3 - x) = -3/2"
shows  "x = 51/8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all solutions to the equation $\displaystyle\sqrt[3]{3 - x} = -\frac{3}{2}$. The final Answer is \frac{51}{8}
 ### Proof
 We get rid of the cube root sign by cubing both sides. This gives us $3-x = -\frac{27}{8}$.
 Solving this equation gives $x = 3 + \frac{27}{8} = \boxed{\frac{51}{8}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "root 3 (3 - x) = -3/2"
shows  "x = 51/8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ that satisfies the equation $\sqrt[3]{3 - x} = -\frac{3}{2}$. The final answer is $\frac{51}{8}$.
